features.popup:
◆ Iny-28 — Bishop Area

Type: Petroglyphs

County: Inyo County

Location: Near Bishop, Owens Valley

Style: Great Basin Curvilinear

Elements: Circles, curvilinear meanders

Tribal affiliation: Owens Valley Paiute (Numa)

Source: Heizer & Baumhoff, Prehistoric Rock Art of Nevada and Eastern California, 1962, Appendix F

◆ Iny-194 — Laws Area

Type: Petroglyphs

County: Inyo County

Location: Near Laws, northern Owens Valley

Style: Great Basin Curvilinear

Tribal affiliation: Owens Valley Paiute (Numa)

Source: Heizer & Baumhoff, Prehistoric Rock Art of Nevada and Eastern California, 1962, Appendix F

◆ Iny-208 — Volcanic Tableland / Chalfant Valley

Type: Major petroglyph complex — hundreds of panels

County: Inyo County

Location: Volcanic Tableland, north of Bishop

Style: Great Basin Representational AND Curvilinear

Key motifs: Bighorn sheep (dominant), hunting scenes with atlatls, human figures with headdresses

Date: ca. 3,500+ years ago

Tribal affiliation: Owens Valley Paiute (Numa)

Source: Heizer & Baumhoff, Prehistoric Rock Art of Nevada and Eastern California, 1962, Appendix F

Type: Petroglyphs

County: Inyo County

Figures: F-10, F-11

Style: Great Basin Representational / Curvilinear

Tribal affiliation: Owens Valley Paiute

Source: Heizer & Baumhoff, Prehistoric Rock Art of Nevada and Eastern California, 1962, Appendix F

◆ Iny-271 — Near Coso Range

Type: Major petroglyph site

County: Inyo County

Location: Southern Owens Valley, near China Lake / Coso Range area

Figures: F-13a, F-15, F-19, F-21, F-21d

Style: Great Basin Representational

Key motifs: Bighorn sheep, anthropomorphs with elaborate headdresses

Tribal affiliation: Coso / Owens Valley Paiute / Shoshone

Source: Heizer & Baumhoff, Prehistoric Rock Art of Nevada and Eastern California, 1962, Appendix F

◆ Iny-272 — Swansea Petroglyphs (Solar Observatory)

Type: Petroglyphs & solar calendrical observatory

County: Inyo County

Location: Near ghost town of Swansea, north shore of Owens Lake

Description: Several hundred petroglyphs on white dolomitic marble. EQUINOX MARKER: 6 vertical bars that predict the actual equinox within hours.

Key motifs: Rayed circles, 6-bar equinox marker, spirals, atlatl, bighorn sheep

Date: Radiocarbon min age ~2,060 years; site likely spans 4,000+ years

Tribal affiliation: Owens Valley Paiute / Shoshone

Source: Heizer & Baumhoff, Prehistoric Rock Art of Nevada and Eastern California, 1962, Appendix F

★ Ch-71 — Deer Creek Canyon (Appendix E)

Type: Petroglyphs at natural game ambush point

County: Elko County, Nevada

Location: Narrow canyon on the east fork of the Jarbidge River

Discovered: 1959 by William Wright Jr.

Elements: Curvilinear meanders, snakes, mountain sheep, human figures, shield figures

Style: Great Basin Abstract Curvilinear

Tribal affiliation: Western Shoshone / Northern Paiute

Source: Heizer & Baumhoff, Prehistoric Rock Art of Nevada and Eastern California, 1962, Appendix F

◆ El-25 — Elko County Petroglyph

Type: Petroglyphs

County: Elko County, Nevada

Style: Great Basin Curvilinear

Source: Heizer & Baumhoff 1962, Appendix E

Tribal affiliation: Western Shoshone

Source: Heizer & Baumhoff, Prehistoric Rock Art of Nevada and Eastern California, 1962, Appendix F

★ Petroglyph Point — Lava Beds National Monument

Type: Massive petroglyph panel — 5,000+ individual carvings

Site number: Mod-1

County: Modoc County

Location: Lava Beds National Monument, SE of Tulelake

Description: One of the largest panels of Native American rock art in California. Over 5,000 individual carvings in soft volcanic tuff.

Key motifs: Geometric patterns, circles, dots, abstract designs

Date: Possibly 6,000+ years old

Tribal affiliation: Modoc

Source: Heizer & Baumhoff, Prehistoric Rock Art of Nevada and Eastern California, 1962, Appendix F
